Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 41052 
October 2007 
 
 
 
Supporting Network of Research Institutes and Think 
Tanks in South Asia Phase II
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADBI  –  Asian Development Bank Institute 
  CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  GMS  –  Greater Mekong Subregion 
  RCI  –  regional cooperation and integration 
  RCSP  –  regional cooperation strategy and program 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  SAARC  –  South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation 
  SARD  –  South Asia Department 
  SSTA  –  small scale technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, regional cooperation, capacity 
development 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling markets, client

NOTES 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice President  L. Jin, Operations Group 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  Y. Kojima, Country Coordination and Regional Cooperation Division, 
SARD 
   
Team leader  S. Bando, Economist, SARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the summit of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) in 
Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 2005, SAARC leaders agreed on the need for the group to “broaden its 
engagement  with  civil  society  organizations,  professional  groups  and  entrepreneurs  in  the 
region.” However, public opinion and the overall climate for regional cooperation remain weak. 
This lack of adequately positive climate in favor of regional cooperation could be addressed by 
independent and reputable research institutes and think tanks in the region as the work done by 
these bodies highlights the benefits of regional cooperation and thus influences public opinion 
and the thinking of political leaders. There appears to be a need for some greater attention to be 
given to strengthening the capability of research institutes, think tanks and experts, and to 
promoting effective networking among them for strengthening regional cooperation. Enhancing 
analytical  and  research  capabilities  and  establishing  an  effective  network  among  research 
organizations  are  generally  referred  to  as  “track  two”  measures  to  distinguish  them  from 
measures directed at governments and public sector agencies. The output from studies by 
research institutes, think tanks and experts will contribute toward molding public opinion and 
could  be  expected  to  influence  positively  the  views  of  leaderships  in  the  region,  thereby 
contributing to stronger political will for regional cooperation. In addition, the report of the 
Eminent Persons Group1 highlights the importance of ADB’s role as a platform for sharing 
information  about  knowledge  management  activities  in  terms  of  regional  know-how.  The 
proposed regional technical assistance (RETA) responds to requests by developing member 
countries (DMCs) at several meetings, including ADB’s annual meeting in Kyoto, Japan, from 5 
to 7 May 2007. The RETA was not included in the South Asia Regional Cooperation Strategy 
and Program (RCSP) 2006–2008, but the concept paper for the RETA was cleared on 18 July 
2007 by the Vice President, Operations 1. During a fact-finding mission from 30 August to 3 
September 2007, major research institutes in South Asia were consulted and agreed with the 
proposed RETA. The RETA design and monitoring framework is shown in Appendix 1.2
 
II.  ISSUES 
 2.   Most  South  Asian  countries  have  fairly  well  developed  and  analytically  oriented 
research institutes, think tanks and experts. Many of these undertake studies related specifically 
to regional cooperation, and their work is beginning to have a positive impact as policy makers 
in the region develop greater appreciation of the benefits of regional cooperation. However, the 
activities in conducting research and disseminating findings remain somewhat limited. In view of 
the significant role that regional cooperation can potentially play in accelerating the pace of 
development and reducing poverty in South Asia, the activities of research institutes, think tanks 
and experts need to be strengthened further by supporting (i) a timely and enhanced scope of 
analytical  work  on  regional  cooperation  activities,  and  (ii)  wider  dissemination  of  research 
findings to encourage policy recommendations being put into practice.  
 
3.  In 2004 ADB undertook a regional small scale technical assistance (SSTA) to promote 
regional cooperation in South Asia, by facilitating “track two” measures to enhance the capacity 
of  research  institutes  in  South  Asia.3  Through  the  SSTA,  ADB  has  promoted  regional 
cooperation by (i) strengthening current initiatives and networks of research institutes, and

2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 14 September 2007.

2   
enhancing the scope of analytical work undertaken; (ii) increasing interaction among regional 
experts;  and  (iii)  widening  the  dissemination  of  research  material  that  supports  regional 
cooperation. Positive evaluation of the “track two” measures to promote regional cooperation 
and integration (RCI), and further recent positive developments in cooperation in the SAARC 
region,  under  the  SSTA,  led  ADB’s  South  Asia  Department  (SARD)  to  conduct  several 
additional activities for the SAARC summit in New Delhi, India, in April 2007. SAARC also 
prioritizes knowledge sharing among its member countries. For example, leaders at the latest 
summit agreed to the vision of a South Asian community where goods, services, peoples, 
technologies, knowledge, capital, culture and ideas flow smoothly around the region.4
 
4.  The SSTA has successfully conducted five studies on specialized topics and supported 
four workshop or seminars on regional cooperation. This includes inputs for the SAARC summit, 
undertaken by the South Asian Centre of Policy Studies, one of the most established networks 
of research institutes in the region. The SSTA also supported the eighth annual conference of 
the  South  Asia  Network  of  Economic  Research  Institutes,  also  a  well-established  regional 
network, which was held in Kathmandu, Nepal, from 31 August to 1 September 2007. The 
conference covered a variety of topics including foreign direct investment, human resource 
development, and development of the financial and agriculture sectors. 
 
5.  These  seminars  and  studies  succeeded  in  raising  awareness  about  key  areas  of 
regional cooperation such as investment cooperation, energy cooperation, South Asia’s strategy 
for World Trade Organization negotiations, the South Asian Free Trade Area, macroeconomic 
policy harmonization, and a Citizens’ Charter for South Asia. However, such initiatives need to 
be enhanced further in order to gain broader socio-political support for regional cooperation. 
The current favorable environment provides an opportunity to push the regional cooperation 
agenda further. ADB’s unique and close involvement with sub-regional cooperation initiatives 
puts it in a strong position to take the process further by assisting to build broad consensus for 
cooperation initiatives through activities to be undertaken by research institutes in the region. 
 
6.  During the SSTA’s implementation, research institutes, think tanks and experts in South 
Asia proposed many useful, practical and constructive research plans and related workshops to 
promote regional cooperation, including policy recommendations. They have since requested 
more timely and wider-scale support from ADB to (i) develop a medium-term framework to 
promote their research activities and “track two” measures, (ii) enhance their research capacity, 
and (iii) further develop research networks in South Asia. In the coming years, these research 
institutes, with capacity to conduct useful research, including addressing policy implications and 
making recommendations, plan to undertake many important studies on regional cooperation. 
These studies need to be completed and delivered through publications and workshops in a 
timely manner. They will be built on lessons of the SSTA and other regional cooperation 
activities. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The proposed RETA will promote regional economic cooperation in South Asia through 
knowledge sharing on RCI and policy making for RCI, and enhance the capacity of research 
institutes  in  South  Asian  DMCs  through  studies,  workshops  and  dissemination  of  the 
                                                 
4  SAARC. 2007.  Declaration of the Fourteenth SAARC Summit. New Delhi.

3
outcomes.5 The RETA will further strengthen existing networks of research institutes in South 
Asia, and facilitate interaction between academics, policy makers and researchers in order to 
promote the “track two” measures. The RETA supports research on RCI issues by DMC experts 
as well as existing research institutes and networks in the region. The studies and workshops 
under the RETA will recommend policies and plans of joint actions to enhance cooperation 
among the SAARC member countries. The studies and workshops may also identify priority 
areas  and  projects  for  which  technical  and  financial  assistance  could  be  provided  by 
development  partners,  including  ADB,  and  further  facilitate  coordination  of  development 
partners in the region. 
 
8.  The RETA will build knowledge and capacity in specific development topics related to 
regional cooperation. It will help to enhance the understanding and awareness of policy makers 
and the public regarding important regional sectoral and thematic issues. It also will strengthen 
ADB’s partnership with local research institutes, think tanks, experts and academia, which will 
facilitate ADB’s recommendations on regional cooperation.6 The RETA will foster knowledge 
communities  throughout  the  region  and  provide  learning  opportunities  on  key  and  priority 
development topics where ADB’s financial assistance is made available for research in regional 
cooperation. The expected development of research networks may be integrated into ADB’s 
lending operations and knowledge management activities, which is in line with the report of the 
Eminent Persons Group to the President proposing ADB as a platform for knowledge sharing 
rather than as the primary source of knowledge. In addition, the network will support DMCs in 
their development efforts and enhance ADB’s ability to respond to their needs more effectively 
and in a timely manner. Research activities to be proposed will primarily cover regional and 
subregional  economic  cooperation  programs  on  cross-border  infrastructure  and  related 
software, trade and investment cooperation and integration, and cooperation in regional public 
goods, which are three of four pillars in ADB’s RCI strategy.7  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The  RETA  will  identify  two  research  institute  networks  in  the  region  to  serve  as 
coordinating centers for specific research topics particularly related to regional cooperation, to 
be financed under the assistance. The networks should have the technical skills and capacity to 
undertake these activities and to influence policy makers to implement their recommendations. 
ADB will identify research topics and research institute networks through internal consultation 
among relevant departments, the Asian Development Bank Institute (ADBI), DMCs and other 
stakeholders.  Research  networks  will  consult  and  coordinate  with  their  regional  network 
institutes  on  the  details  of  research  activities.  They  will  advertise  the  details  of  research 
activities  to  be  financed  through  their  networks  on  their  websites  in  order  to  encourage 
additional collaboration and support from experts in the region. These coordinating centers will 
hold  workshops  on  related  topics  to  disseminate  research  outcomes.  To  ensure  effective 
synergy  and  knowledge  sharing,  research  networks  and  their  member  institutes  will 
communicate with each other as much as possible. To further promote regional cooperation and 
integration  through  “track  two”  measures,  the  networks  will  also  collaborate  with  existing 
research institute networks and governments in the region. In order to build on lessons learnt 
and  find  effective  ways  to  see  relevant  governments  realize  policy  recommendations, 
workshops to discuss case studies of “track two” measures in South Asia and other regions will 
be held during the early stages of implementing the RETA.  
                                                 
5  The RETA will be conducted in SAARC member countries Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, 
Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. 
6  ADB. 2007. Supporting Provision of Regional Public Goods in the Asia and Pacific Region. Manila. 
7  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila.

4   
 
10.  The outputs of the RETA will be a series of operational policy studies and analytical 
works  on  development  of  RCI  in  South  Asia,  workshops,  seminars  and  conferences,  and 
dissemination  of  the  findings  of  these  studies  through  publication  and  the  internet.  The 
workshops will involve a variety of stakeholders, including representatives of the private sector, 
to facilitate dissemination of the findings and effectively influence policy makers. A set of papers 
and studies will be generated by local research institutes that are members of a research 
network in SAARC member countries. The studies will cover regional cooperation in areas such 
as  transport,  trade  and  investment,  energy,  macroeconomic  policies,  health  and  migration 
issues, many of which are priority sectors in the South Asia RCSP 2006–2008. Each network of 
research institutes, working as a coordinating center, will be asked to conduct a stocktaking 
study of research activities for each sector to avoid redundant work and identify research topics 
in each area. 
 
11.  In addition to supporting two research institute networks, a portion of research grant 
funds will be available to research institutes in the region that are not already part of the 
networks. Competitive research grants, open to all research institutes and experts in the region, 
will be developed and implemented to promote research on regional cooperation by research 
institutes, think tanks and experts from SAARC countries. A steering committee8 will receive 
and select proposals to be financed by grants. For research proposals under coordinating 
centers and competitive research grants, a template for proposals and evaluation criteria will be 
developed to ensure a uniform process. 
 
12.  Synergies with ADBI will be explored in the design of workshops and the selection of 
studies to be conducted.9 The RETA also will explore opportunities for cooperation with the 
research and training institutes of other multilateral institutions such as the World Bank Institute. 
The RETA will build on the lessons and extensive experience of other subregional cooperation 
programs, such as the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Program, the GMS Phnom Penh Plan 
for Development Management, the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
Program, the CAREC Capacity Development for Regional Cooperation in CAREC Participating 
Countries,10 studies, workshops and training courses conducted by the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration and the SSTA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The  total  cost  of  the  proposed  RETA,  estimated  at  $1,200,000  equivalent,  will  be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  costs  will cover  consulting 
services,  regional  conferences,  the  research  program  and  publication.  The  detailed  cost 
estimates for the proposed RETA are given in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency of the RETA. ADB’s SARD will be responsible for 
overall administration of the assistance. The RETA is expected to begin in December 2007 and 
be  completed  by  December  2010.  The  selected  networks  of  research  institutes  will  be 
implementing agencies. No activities will be financed under this RETA in any member country of 
                                                 
8  See paragraph 15 of this paper. 
9  ADBI held an Asian think tanks workshop in June 2007.  
10 ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation: Capacity Development for 
Regional Cooperation in CAREC Participating  Countries, Phase I. Manila (TA 6375-REG, approved on 18 
December).

5
ADB unless and until a letter of no objection regarding such activity has been received from the 
government of such member country. 
 
15.  A steering committee chaired by the director of the Country Coordination and Regional 
Cooperation Division, SARD, will oversee the RETA. The committee members will be the team 
leader who will be a staff member of ADB and supervise the RETA on a daily basis, economists 
at ADB, and the program manager. The steering committee, supported by the program manager, 
will be set up to direct and maintain high quality research in close consultation with networks of 
research institutes. It will ensure the quality of research to be conducted by member research 
institutes. The committee will also screen research project proposals and identify resource 
people for workshops. It will meet periodically to review progress and resolve issues. In addition, 
the committee will have the right to select studies to be financed under competitive research 
grants. A full-time program secretariat based at ADB headquarters will provide logistical and 
administrative support to the committee.  
 
16.  The RETA will require consulting services including a program manager (international, 
12 person-months) and a full-time program officer based in Manila (national, 36 person-months). 
Both consultants will be individually recruited and will work under the supervision of the team 
leader, an ADB staff member responsible for administration of the RETA. The outline terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The program manager will report to SARD and 
will  be  responsible  for  (i)  identifying  networks  of  research  institutes  and  preparing  draft 
agreements  with  them;  (ii)  organizing  workshops  to  discuss  case  studies  of  “track  two” 
measures; (iii) providing necessary technical assistance; (iv) reviewing the activities and outputs 
of these research networks; (v) assessing the research proposals to be financed under the 
RETA, including competitive grants; and (vi) managing a competitive grants program. All the 
consultants will be engaged by ADB according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time).  
 
17.  Appropriate information on RETA activities, including relevant applications for research 
activities, outputs from the research grant program, and the agenda and outputs of workshops 
will be disseminated widely through the websites of ADB and local research institutes, as well 
as publications. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
18.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,200,000  on  a  grant  basis  for  Supporting  Network  of 
Research Institutes and Think Tanks in South Asia Phase II.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The technical assistance will require inputs from international or national consultants with 
expertise in the identified areas and drawn from a range of experts, research institutes and think 
tanks to provide analytical and operationally relevant inputs. The consultants should also have 
expertise in designing frameworks for knowledge sharing and dissemination, and learning and 
dissemination plans in research outputs. 
 
B.  International Consultant (12 person-months)  
2.   The consultant will be a technical specialist as the program manager in the identified areas. 
The consultant will have expertise in techniques for knowledge transfer. He or she will design and 
develop in-depth knowledge products and services that match the needs identified in the region, 
developing member countries (DMCs) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The consultant 
needs to have a good understanding of relevant subjects and relevant research techniques. The 
tasks of the consultant will include but not be limited to the following. 
 
(i)  Identify networks of research institutes and think tanks in South Asia, noting which 
networks serve as coordinating centers for specific topics, to be financed under the 
RETA. Research institutes networks should have the technical skills and capacity to 
undertake the specified activities. 
(ii)  Identify specific research activities and assess the suitability of experts in the network 
member research institutes for involvement in each of these activities.  
(iii)  Prepare draft agreements with networks of research institutes and think tanks identified 
under the RETA, and undertake necessary preparatory work. 
(iv)  In  the  early  stage  of  implementation,  organize  workshops  for  stocktaking  of  past 
experience in “track two” measures undertaken in South Asia and other regions. 
(v)  Design  a  format  or  template  to  be  used  for  research  and  workshop  and  seminar 
proposals, as well as for competitive research grants. 
(vi)  Review  the  proposals  from  research  institute  networks,  and  provide  comments  to 
ensure quality of research. 
(vii)  Manage a competitive research grants program, together with other steering committee 
members; review the research project proposals; provide comments to ensure quality of 
research; and select the proposed studies and workshops and seminars to be financed. 
(viii)  Support the organization of seminars and workshops, and conduct them. 
(ix)  Prepare progress reports, conduct a midterm review and make presentations to the 
steering committee. 
(x)  Coordinate with relevant internal and external parties. 
(xi)  Provide inputs at different stages of the RETA implementation. 
(xii)  Coordinate various activities required for successful completion of the RETA. 
(xiii)  Undertake  other  tasks  determined  jointly  with  ADB  staff  members  managing  the 
program.

10  Appendix 3 
 
C.  National Consultant (36 person-months) 
3.  The consultant, in close collaboration with the program manager and the team leader, will 
support and manage the day-to-day implementation of the program. He or she will be based at 
ADB headquarters and will report to the program manager and the team leader. Candidates 
preferably must have a postgraduate degree in economics, social science or public administration 
and public policy; proven experience in managing technical assistance projects; and at least five 
years’ professional experience in dealing with a range of stakeholders. Previous experience in 
capacity-building programs in academic and non-academic settings will be a distinct advantage.  
 
4.  Specific tasks will include, but will not be limited to, the following. 
 
(i)  Assist ADB and the program manager in coordinating all activities under the RETA. This 
includes liaising with participating research institutes within and outside the selected 
networks, and helping to monitor RETA progress and its administration. 
(ii)  Assist in organizing seminars and workshops under the RETA by taking care of all 
logistical arrangements, including travel, hotel reservations and venue arrangements. 
(iii)  Assist in organizing and implementing steering committee meetings. 
(iv)  Assist ADB and the program manager in preparing, disseminating and publishing RETA 
outputs. 
(v)  Assist in managing the websites of ADB and research institute networks.
